get cones from message and call the cone ordering algorithm and return the results

Parameters:

Returns:

global_path.dynamics module

global_path.dynamics.continuous_dynamics_fixed_x_order(x, u, l_r=0.5, l_f=0.5, m=1.0)[source]

Defines dynamics of the car, i.e. equality constraints. parameters: state x = [xPos,yPos,v,theta] input u = [F,phi]

global_path.dynamics.discrete_custom_integrator(n=3, l_r=0.5, l_f=0.5, m=1.0)[source]

makes a discrete dynamics function using the bicycle model with the given parameters. uses the midpoint method for integration.

Parameters:

  • n (int, optional) – number of timesteps to use for the midpoint method. Defaults to 3.

  • l_r (float, optional) – distance (m) from rear axle of car to center of mass. Defaults to 0.5.

  • l_f (float, optional) – distance (m) from front axle of car to center of mass. Defaults to 0.5.

  • m (float, optional) – mass of car. leave at 1.0 to output acceleration. Defaults to 1.0.

Returns:

integrator which takes in (x0: initial state, u: control input, dt: time to integrate forward)

Return type:

casadi.Function

global_path.global_opt_compiled module

class global_path.global_opt_compiled.CompiledGlobalOpt(N, nlp_solver='ipopt', solver_opts=None, car_params={'l_f': 1.5213, 'l_r': 1.4987, 'm': 1.0}, bbox={'l': 2, 'w': 1}, **constraints)[source]

Bases: object

DEFAULT_SOPTS = {'ipopt': {'expand': True, 'ipopt.linear_solver': 'ma57'}, 'snopt': {'expand': False}, 'worhp': {'expand': True, 'worhp.NLPprint': -1}}
angle(a, b)[source]
construct_solver(generate_c=False, compile_c=False, use_c=False, gcc_opt_flag='-Ofast')[source]

creates a solver object

Parameters:

  • generate_c (bool, optional) – whether or not to generate new C code. Defaults to False.

  • compile_c (bool, optional) – whether or not to look for and compile the C code. Defaults to False.

  • use_c (bool, optional) – whether or not to load the compiled C code. Defaults to False.

  • gcc_opt_flag (str, optional) – optimization flags to pass to GCC. can be -O1, -O2, -O3, or -Ofast depending on how long you’re willing to wait. Defaults to ‘-Ofast’.

load_solver()[source]

alternative to construct_solver if you’re just loading a saved solver.

solve(left, right)[source]

crunch the numbers.

Parameters:

  • left (np.ndarray) – location of left cones. shape (N, 2).

  • right (np.ndarray) – location of right cones. shape (N, 2).

Returns:

result of solve. keys ‘z’ (states), ‘u’ (controls), ‘t’ (timestamps)

Return type:

dict

to_constant_tgrid(dt, z, u, t)[source]

converts a solver result to a constant-dt representation. z, u, and t can be passed in with **res (from solve())

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – desired resultant time discretization interval

  • z (np.ndarray) – states from solver

  • u (np.ndarray) – controls from solver

  • t (np.ndarray) – timestamps from solver

Returns:

arrays of states, controls

Return type:

(np.ndarray, np.ndarray)
